Award.AwardTitle: Arithmetic and Geometry of Calabi-Yau Varieties Workshop
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past three decades, the geometry of Calabi-Yau varieties has been a central topic in mathematics and physics. The workshop ``Arithmetic and Geometry of Calabi-Yau varieties'' to be held at the Fields Institute (Aug 16-25, 2011) aims to survey the recent developments of the subject with a focus on the interplay of techniques coming from arithmetic and algebraic geometry in the study of Calabi-Yau varieties (esp. Calabi-Yau threefolds and K3 surfaces). Moreover, as a long-term impact, the workshop will explore new directions in the field of Calabi-Yau varieties and related areas (such as hyperkahler varieties).

The ten day workshop will be both research and training oriented. Specifically, the first three days will be devoted to introductory lectures for graduate students and postdocs. The second part of the workshop will consist of research talks given by experts in the field. Additionally, the workshop will encourage research activities in small working groups, as well as the mentoring of the graduate students and postdocs by the senior participants. The NSF funding will be used to facilitate the participation of US based mathematicians and physicists to this workshop. Most of the funds will be used for the support of junior participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has supported the participation of 24 US based researchers at the workshop "Arithmetic and Geometry of K3 surfaces and Calabi-Yau threefolds" that was held at the Fields Institute (Toronto, Canada) between August 16-25, 2011. The workshop was a major international conference focused on the study of Calabi-Yau varieties, one of the most active fields in mathematics and theoretical physics. The Calabi-Yau threefolds are an essential ingredient for a theoretical understanding of the universe via String Theory. The aim of the workshop was to survey this important topic and to open new research directions. The workshop has attracted numerous world-class experts from US, Canada, Japan, and Europe.

In addition to state-of-art research activities, the workshop was focused on the training of the junior participants (graduate students and postdocs). For example. the workshop has started with a series of introductory lectures targeted towards this groups. This award was used with priority for the support of US junior researchers, assuring in this way a strong and vibrant research on this topic in the future.

A proceedings volume for this workshop will appear in the "Fields Institute Communications" Series. Also, a follow-up semester-long thematic program will be held at the Fields Institute in the Fall of 2013.
